Description: Rim and body sherd (mended from two fragments) of Corinthian black-figured pottery lekane with lug handle; glaze fired red-brown; interior: glazed with added white and added red bands; top of rim glazed with one group of four white vertical strokes; exterior: outside of handle reserved with one band; two bands at top of wall; below, black-figure decoration consisting of panther (only head remaining), to right; incised splinter rosette as filling ornament; inscription on top of rim.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Painter of Athens 931
Curator's comments: The sherd is from the same vase as British Museum 1886,0401.1043.b. The sherd probably belongs to the same vase as British Museum 1886,0401.1009 and 1886, 0401.994, as well as either 1886, 0401.1008 or 1886,0401.1054. For the shape, see British Museum 1861,0425.46. C.W. Neeft (personal communication) considers that the lekane is the work of the Painter of Athens 931.
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B102.7.3)
Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 91, no. A120)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 219, no. 35)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.116) (Phase 1)
